newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia's NSW breaks monthly wheat export record.
newsitem.headline: Australia's NSW breaks monthly wheat export record.

text.p: The Australian Wheat Board said on Wednesday its New South Wales state division had broken its monthly record for wheat shipments, shipping 750,000 tonnes of exports in June.
The AWB said the figure exceeded the previous best this year of 600,000 tonnes, set in May, and brought the state's total so far for the 1996/97 year ending September 30 to over four million tonnes.

"Our ability to market the crop is important but to move grain in the first six months of the year means improved prices for growers and requires a mammoth shipping and chartering exercise," Ted Laskie, the AWB NSW state manager, said in a statement.

"Our objective was to front end the shipping programme which has been achieved this year with vessels queueing at both the Newcastle and Port Kembla terminals ready to load as soon as previously berthed ships have sailed.
"This is a position we have not been in for over 10 years," he added.
The AWB said rail wagons had been brought in from South Australia, coal wagons had been converted to grain, and port terminals and regional receival sites operated around the clock.
The AWB had also used road transport to supplement rail deliveries.
Laskie said the monthly shipping record could stand for some time given that a large percentage of the crop had already moved.
Australia produced a record 23.6 million tonnes of wheat in 1996/97.
